In addition, the polynomial must satisfy P(1) ≡ 1 (mod 4).

Decide whether there exists a polynomial P(x) meeting these criteria, and justify your answer.
secondary_category: 2.2 Ring Theory, Field Theory, and Polynomial Algebra

question:
A company uses an efficiency score defined by 
  F = 8·|cos(2θ)|,
where θ is an angle determined by the ratio of two performance indices such that tan θ = 5⁄3. (Note: if cos(2θ) is negative, its absolute value is used in computing F.) Calculate F for the department having this ratio.
secondary_category: 6.2 Optimal Control, Variational Methods, and Optimization

question: A school concert requires arranging chairs on a stage. On each stage, chairs are set up in rows so that every row except the last has 4 chairs, while the final row has only 3 chairs due to stage design restrictions. If 7 stages are prepared and together they can seat 161 students, how many rows does each stage have?

A contractor orders exactly enough lumber for a building project: 4/9 of a cubic yard of oak lumber and 5/11 of a cubic yard of pine lumber. When the project is completed, he finds that he used 75% of his oak lumber but only 1/3 of his pine lumber. How many cubic yards of lumber remain unused?
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question: A museum display case is built in the shape of a rectangular box with dimensions 6, 8, and 10 meters. For security reasons, a laser alarm system is installed throughout all points that lie either outside the case but within 3 meters of it or exactly on its surface; however, the interior of the case itself is not monitored. Determine the volume of the monitored region (that is, the set of all points that are not inside the case but lie within 3 meters of it) and show that it can be written in the form (m + nπ)/p, where m, n, and p are positive integers with n and p relatively prime.

A municipal committee is reviewing bids (expressed in thousands of dollars) for a new public park project. Based on past experience, the average bid is 100 with a standard deviation of 20. To promote fair competition, only bids that fall between one standard deviation below and one standard deviation above the average (i.e. between 80 and 120, inclusive) will be considered. All bids are whole numbers (in thousands). In addition, to ensure an emphasis on higher-value proposals, the committee requires that at least half of the different bid amounts in its final selection are strictly greater than the average (that is, greater than 100). Finally, if a bid is exactly equal to either endpoint (80 or 120), only one such bid is allowed in the selection. Assuming that no two bids share the same amount (so each bid’s amount is distinct), what is the maximum number of distinct bid values the committee can select?

Let a be a fixed integer with a ≥ 2. For n ≥ a + 1, define 
  Lₙ(a) = lcm(a, a + 1, …, n).
Determine all positive integers n (in terms of a) for which 
  Lₙ₋₁(a) = Lₙ(a).
In your answer, give a complete proof and explain separately the cases when a is prime and when a is composite.

Consider n factories arranged in a circle and numbered F₁, F₂, …, Fₙ (with n ≥ 2). Initially, factory Fᵢ holds exactly 2i crates. The management wishes to redistribute the crates so that after the process factory Fᵢ holds exactly 2(n + 2 – i) crates. The only permitted operation is as follows: in one move you may select any two crates (they may come from the same factory or from two different factories) and transfer one crate from its source factory to the immediately clockwise neighbor and the other crate from its source factory to the immediately counterclockwise neighbor. (Note that when a crate is taken from a factory, you may choose independently from which factory each of the two selected crates comes.) 

Moreover, due to a temporary logistical bonus program, if at any moment after a move a factory’s current crate count is an even number, that factory must immediately receive an extra shipment of 2 crates (this bonus shipment happens instantly and only once at the moment the factory’s total becomes even; it does not recur if the factory remains even later).

Determine all positive integers n for which it is possible, by a finite sequence of moves, to reach the target configuration.

A jewelry designer is creating custom crystal necklaces for an upcoming exhibition. Each necklace is made with a total of 40 crystals, using red and blue crystals in a ratio of 3 to 5. She plans to craft 12 necklaces. 

a) How many red and blue crystals does she need in total? 

b) If 15% of all crystals are expected to break during assembly and must be replaced, how many crystals should she prepare before starting her work?

Jenna organized a weekend fundraiser. On Saturday, she received $250 from small donors and $300 from large donors. On Sunday, she collected a total of $360, with the donations from small donors being twice as much as those from large donors. However, 10% of the combined funds were pledges that were not received immediately. How many dollars did Jenna actually receive over the weekend?
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
An electronics company finds that its monthly sales (in thousands of units), y, are linearly related to its advertising expenditure (in thousands of dollars), x, via the market study equation

  (5, –3) · ((x, y) – (2, 8)) = 15.

(a) Rewrite this relationship in slope–intercept form, y = mx + b, and state the ordered pair (m, b).

(b) If the company increases its advertising expenditure by 4 (i.e. from the initial level), determine the percentage increase in monthly sales relative to the sales level at x = 2.
secondary_category: 6.2 Optimal Control, Variational Methods, and Optimization

question: An elliptical arch is built as an acoustic reflector so that any sound originating at one focus is reflected to the other. The arch’s full shape is part of an ellipse centered at the origin with its major axis along the x‐axis. One of the foci is located at (3, 0), and the ratio of the total lengths of the major and minor axes is 5 to 4. Find (a) the standard equation of the ellipse and (b) the distance between the two foci.

A decagonal oblique prism has all lateral faces as parallelograms. Due to design requirements, in each lateral face one of the interior angles measures α and the lengths of the two sides forming that angle are in the fixed ratio 2 : 7. For structural stability, it is also required that α is less than 120°. Determine all possible values of α that can occur under these conditions, considering separately the cases when α is acute and when it is obtuse.

A telecommunications company is installing a high-speed cable between two communication towers located at A(3, –2, 7) and B(8, 4, 1). City regulations require that the cable be laid in two parts: first, a horizontal cable run along the ground connecting the points directly beneath the towers, and then a vertical cable run up the side of tower B to reach its transmission equipment.

• The horizontal installation (i.e., the cable laid on the ground from the projection of A to the projection of B) costs $12 per meter.
• The vertical installation (from ground level at tower B up to its top) costs $18 per meter.

(a) Compute the horizontal distance based on the projections of A and B onto the ground.
(b) Determine the vertical distance along tower B.
(c) Calculate the total installation cost following this two-segment route.
(d) For comparison, if the cable could be installed directly in a straight line at a uniform rate of $15 per meter, compute the straight-line distance between A and B, the corresponding installation cost, and then find the ratio of the actual (two-segment) installation cost to the straight-line installation cost.

In a modern art museum, an exhibit features five identical square panels arranged in a row so that each panel touches its neighbor along an entire side. This configuration produces 12 distinct vertices. An artist plans to paint each vertex with one of four colors—green, yellow, red, or blue—with the rule that any two vertices joined by a side of a square must be painted in different colors. In addition, the two vertices at the far left of the first panel and the far right of the last panel must be painted blue, and no other vertex may be blue. How many different valid colorings of the 12 vertices are possible under these constraints?

A circular park is defined by the equation
  x² – 8x + y² – 6y + 13 = 0.
A jogging track runs along the line y = 2, which divides the park into two sections. In the section of the park above the jogging track, a rectangular fountain measuring 2 by 5 units is to be installed (assume the entire rectangle lies within the upper section).

(a) Find the area of the portion of the park that lies above the line y = 2.

(b) Subtracting the area of the fountain from the area found in part (a), determine the net area available in the upper section. Then, verify whether this net area is at least 60% of the total area of the park.

A community center is renovating its garden by installing a fence. They allocate 75% of a total fencing budget of $4800 for a rectangular garden, and the fence costs $12 per meter. If the garden’s length is 40 meters longer than its width, what are the garden’s dimensions?

Alpha, Beta, and Gamma are three locations connected by two distinct shipping routes. One route is a direct railway line from Alpha to Gamma. The alternative “combined‐mode” route uses a road leg from Alpha to Beta followed by a highway leg from Beta to Gamma. It is known that

  (a) the highway distance from Beta to Gamma is 50 km longer than the direct railway distance from Alpha to Gamma, and 
  (b) the total distance of the combined road–highway route is 70 km longer than the direct railway distance.

In addition, shipping one ton of cargo along the direct railway route costs 360 rubles, while shipping one ton from Alpha to Beta by road costs 240 rubles. Finally, transporting cargo by road costs 10 rubles more per kilometer than by railway (that is, if the railway cost per km is r rubles, then the road cost per km is r + 10).

Determine:
  • the direct railway distance from Alpha to Gamma,
  • the road distance from Alpha to Beta, and 
  • the highway distance from Beta to Gamma.

Note: In your solution you must first express the per‐kilometer railway cost in terms of the direct railway distance, then use the given cost data together with the distance relations (a) and (b) to find the three distances.

Let a, b, c be positive real numbers representing the areas (in square meters) of three square plots in a landscaping project. The overall efficiency index of the project is defined by

  E = √(abc)·(√a + √b + √c) + (a + b + c)².

(a) Prove that
  √(abc)·(√a + √b + √c) + (a + b + c)² ≥ 5·√(2·abc·(a + b + c)).

(b) Determine all cases in which equality holds.

Problem:

(1) A tech store offers a special discount voucher calculated by the formula
  4·tan 60° – (½)^(–1) + (cos 45° – 2021)⁰ + |sin 45° – (√2⁄2)|.
Evaluate the numerical value of the voucher.

(2) In a promotional pricing campaign, the adjustment factor x for a product satisfies
  (x – 4)(2x + 5) = 7(x – 4).
Determine all possible values of x, taking care to analyze the case when the common factor might be zero.
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
A freelance consultant charges for his services according to the following scheme. When working on a project that requires n (n ≥ 1) hours of consultation, his fee is normally given by F(n) = 6n + 15 dollars. However, for projects that exceed 5 hours, every hour beyond the fifth incurs an extra premium of 2 dollars in addition to the hourly rate indicated above. 

(a) Prove that for projects lasting 5 hours or less, the sequence of total fees {F(n)} forms an arithmetic progression. 

(b) For projects lasting more than 5 hours, express the total fee T(n) as a piecewise function and determine the effective difference between the fees for consecutive hours of consultation (i.e. for n and n + 1) in each segment.

(c) Determine the necessary condition on the extra premium so that the overall fee structure (for all n ≥ 1) forms an arithmetic sequence. Provide a complete justification by considering the two cases separately.

An automotive garage is evaluating the fuel efficiencies of three car models—Alpha, Beta, and Gamma. Before any upgrades, the three models have an average fuel efficiency of 30 miles per gallon (mpg). The combined average fuel efficiency of Models Alpha and Beta is 28 mpg, and that of Models Beta and Gamma is 32 mpg. Later, due to a promotion, Model Beta’s fuel efficiency is improved by 10% (based on its original rating). Determine the original fuel efficiency of Model Beta (in mpg) before the upgrade.

Let Γ be a circle with center O and radius 10. Chord BC of Γ has length 12, and a point A is chosen in the interior of Γ so that ∠BAC = 50°. Outside triangle ABC, construct two isosceles triangles as follows:
 • In triangle ABR, take AB = AR and require that ∠ABR = 90°.
 • In triangle ACP, take AC = AP and require that ∠ACP = 90°.
Next, extend rays BA and CA (beyond A) until they meet Γ again at points E and F, respectively. Then extend line ER (with R from the first isosceles triangle) and line FP (with P from the second isosceles triangle) until they meet Γ again at points X and Y, respectively. Finally, suppose that the chords EX and FY (that is, the segments from E to X and from F to Y measured along Γ) each have length 8.

Prove that the chords BX and CY are equal in length and express this common length in terms of the given numerical values.

An investor’s portfolio (in thousands of dollars) follows a recurrence relation defined as follows. The initial investment I₁ satisfies |I₁| < 100. For every month n ≥ 2 the growth is given by
  if n is odd: 4·Iₙ – Iₙ₋₁ = 3n + 20,
  if n is even: 4·Iₙ – Iₙ₋₁ = 3n + 15.
Determine I₂₅ accurate to 0.000001.
secondary_category: 3.4 Integral Transforms, Integral Equations, and Difference Equations

question:
In rectangle ABCD the sides satisfy AB : BC = 2 : √3. Let E be the midpoint of side AD and let F be a point on side AB (with F ≠ A) chosen so that line EF is perpendicular to line FC. In addition, select point G on side CD so that FG is perpendicular to the diagonal AC. The segments EF and FG (together with portions of the sides of the rectangle) divide ABCD into four non‐overlapping triangles.

(a) Determine the location of F (that is, find the length AF in terms of AB and BC) so that both perpendicularity conditions hold.

(b) Considering all triangles formed by these segments and the sides of the rectangle, analyze the figures case‐by‐case and prove exactly how many distinct pairs of similar triangles exist.

A 1000‐meter cycling race is held between two cyclists, P and Q. Cyclist P rides at a constant speed and finishes the race in 50 seconds. Cyclist Q, however, starts from rest and accelerates uniformly for the first 5 seconds until reaching a constant speed, which he maintains for the rest of the race—finishing the entire course in 60 seconds. At the moment Cyclist P finishes the race, determine how many meters Cyclist Q has traveled and by how many meters P beats Q.

A retail store’s total revenue is composed of three parts: 4 hundred-thousands dollars, 6 ten-thousands dollars, and 5 thousands dollars. 
a) Write the total revenue in its full numerical form.
b) Express the total revenue in terms of “ten thousands dollars”.
c) The store plans to reinvest 20% of its revenue into new inventory. If the reinvestment amount is to be allocated into packages of 10,000 dollars each, determine how many complete packages can be formed and the dollar amount remaining after these packages are assembled.
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
Consider an ellipse given by

  x²/(a²) + y²/(b²) = 1   (with a > b > 0).

It is known that:
 • The eccentricity of the ellipse is 2/3.
 • The distance from the top vertex on the minor axis—that is, the point (0, b)—to the left focus is 5 meters.

(1) Determine the values of a and b and hence write the equation of the ellipse.

(2) A straight walkway is to be constructed so that it passes through the right focus of the ellipse and has a slope of –1/2. This walkway meets the boundary of the ellipse at two distinct points. Find the length of the portion of the walkway that lies inside the ellipse, and then express the ratio of this length to the length of the major axis.

Consider the function
  F(x) = 5·ln x – (1/4)·p·x²           (x > 0, p > 0),
where the positive constant p represents an inflation-related adjustment factor in a pricing model.

(I) If p = 4, determine the interval of x-values on which F(x) is strictly increasing.

(II) To account for additional linear operating expenses in the business model, an adjusted revenue function is defined as
  R(x) = F(x) – (p – 5)·x.
Let x₁ and x₂ (with x₁ < x₂) be two distinct production levels corresponding to points M(x₁, R(x₁)) and N(x₂, R(x₂)) on the graph of R. Assume that the slope k of the secant line joining M and N equals the instantaneous rate of change at some intermediate point x₀, i.e.,
  k = [R(x₂) – R(x₁)]⁄(x₂ – x₁) = R′(x₀).
In practice an adjustment due to a minor processing delay adds a fixed positive offset δ (δ > 0) so that the effective instantaneous rate is evaluated at x₀ + δ rather than at x₀. Prove that under these conditions the relation
  x₁ + x₂ > 2·(x₀ + δ)
holds.

A 10×10 tiled floor is arranged in a perfect chessboard pattern (colors alternating black and white). An art installation designer wishes to cover the entire floor using exactly 24 custom L‑shaped tiles and one square tile. Each L‑tile covers 4 unit squares in an L‐shape and, because of manufacturing constraints, must be placed so that it covers exactly three squares of one color and one square of the other color (rotations are allowed but reflections are not). The square tile is a 2×2 block that always covers exactly two black and two white squares. Prove that no matter how the pieces are arranged under these conditions, the entire 10×10 floor cannot be tiled by these pieces.

Let
  A₍ᵢ₎ = { [1 2i; 0 1] if i is odd  and  [1 3i; 0 1] if i is even } for i = 1, 2, …, 10.
(a) Compute the product P = A₁·A₂·…·A₁₀.
(b) Then, if the transformation represented by P is applied to the point (0, 5), find its image.

(Note: In these 2×2 matrices the notation [a b; c d] means the matrix with first row [a, b] and second row [c, d].)

A laboratory measurement is processed as follows: first, 3 is added to the measured value; next, the sum is multiplied by 8; then the product is divided evenly by 4; finally, 3 is subtracted from the quotient. The resulting number equals one‐half of an unknown constant C. (Note: if the original measured value had been an even number, the multiplier would have been increased from 8 to 10—but in this experiment the original measurement does not trigger this rule.) If the original measurement is 14.5, what is the value of C?
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
In triangle ABC the sides opposite angles A, B, and C are a, b, and c respectively. Suppose a = 3, b = 3√2, and it is given that cos B = –1/3.

(I) Using the Law of Cosines with angle B, determine the measure of angle C.

(II) Allowing side c to vary over all values that yield a valid triangle (with a and b fixed as above and with cos B = –1/3 maintained), find the complete range of possible values for the product sin A · sin C.

A company’s profit margin m(t) (expressed as a decimal) is modeled by m(t) = 0.05 · ln(1 + t), where t is the number of months since launch. For t < 5 the formula applies as given. Beginning with month 5, a new fixed expense reduces the profit margin by 0.02, so for t ≥ 5 the actual margin is m_actual(t) = 0.05 · ln(1 + t) – 0.02. Determine the smallest whole number month t for which the actual profit margin is at least 0.10.
secondary_category: 3.1 Real Analysis, Measure Theory, and Functional Analysis

question:
A collector bought a rare painting for 2500 dollars. He then sold it to an art dealer for a 12% profit. Later, the art dealer sold the painting to a gallery at a 15% loss relative to his purchase price. Finally, the gallery sold the painting back to the original collector for 80% of what the gallery had paid. However, if the painting’s estimated restoration cost exceeds 500 dollars, an additional 5% reduction is applied to the final sale price (if the cost is 500 dollars or less, no extra reduction is made).

Determine the collector’s net gain or loss overall for each of the following cases:
(I) The restoration cost is 450 dollars.
(II) The restoration cost is 600 dollars.
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
Consider the function 
  R(x) = √[1 – (logₘ(n·x))²],
where m and n are positive integers with m > 1. For the device using this function to work properly, its input x must lie within the set where R(x) is defined; that is, where
  –1 ≤ logₘ(n·x) ≤ 1.
A quick calculation shows that this forces x to lie in the closed interval
  [1⁄(m·n), m⁄n].
An engineering specification requires that the length of this interval is exactly 1⁄1024 and, in addition, the maximum permitted input (the right‐endpoint m⁄n) must not exceed 1 volt.

(a) Express n in terms of m using the interval–length condition.

(b) Find the smallest possible sum m + n (with m and n chosen under the above conditions) and determine the remainder when that sum is divided by 1000.

Let
  S = { x ∈ ℝ : x² – 2x – 8 < 0 }
  T = { x ∈ ℝ : –x² + (2p + 3)x – (p² + p – 2) ≤ 0 },
where p ∈ ℝ.

(1) Suppose that “x ∈ S” is a sufficient but not necessary condition for “x ∈ T.” In other words, every x satisfying x² – 2x – 8 < 0 must also satisfy –x² + (2p + 3)x – (p² + p – 2) ≤ 0, yet there exist some x (outside S) that still belong to T. Determine the range of p for which this holds true.

(2) Suppose instead that S and T have no common elements; that is, S ∩ T = ∅. Determine the range of p for which this occurs.

In addition, assume that the vertex of the quadratic defining T is to the right of the vertex of the quadratic defining S. (Recall that the vertex of f(x) = x² – 2x – 8 is at x = 1.) Incorporate this extra condition into your answers.

In right triangle ABC with right angle C, the hypotenuse AB measures 26 meters and angle A is 30°. A circular water feature is to be installed so that its circumference is tangent to side AC, tangent to the hypotenuse AB, and tangent externally to the circumcircle of triangle ABC. 
 
(a) Express the radius r of this water feature in exact form, in terms of the given sides and angle. 
 
(b) An incircle is also drawn inside triangle ABC. Compute the ratio (as a percentage) of the area of the water feature to the area of the incircle.

At an art exhibit, 21 straight beams are suspended so that no two are parallel and no three meet at one point. Focus on one special beam: it meets each of the other 20 beams at a distinct point, and when these 20 points are marked along the beam (from one end of the “active” segment to the other), they divide that portion of the beam into 19 consecutive segments. The artist insists that the lengths (in meters) of these 19 segments form an arithmetic progression with each segment length an integer value, and that the total length from the first to the last marked point is exactly 190 meters. 

Determine all possible choices for the first segment’s length and the common difference of the arithmetic progression that satisfy these conditions.

Two concert venues, Arena X and Arena Y, set ticket prices for a four‐night music festival. On the first night both venues charged the same price. Over the next nights, Arena X raised its ticket price by multiplying the previous night’s price by a fixed factor (so its prices form an increasing geometric sequence), whereas Arena Y increased its price each night by adding the same constant amount (so its prices form an increasing arithmetic sequence). By the end of the festival the total revenue from ticket sales at Arena X exceeded that of Arena Y by exactly 5 dollars, and neither venue’s total revenue exceeded 150 dollars. In addition, Arena X’s ticket price on the fourth night was exactly 1.5 times its price on the first night. Under these conditions, what was the combined revenue from ticket sales for both venues during the first two nights?

A high‐security company uses a special algorithm to generate encryption keys. The algorithm works as follows. First, the company selects seven distinct positions from the Fibonacci sequence (starting with 1, 1, 2, …); at these positions the Fibonacci numbers are 3, 5, 8, 13, 21, 34, and 55. Next, for each selected Fibonacci number n, the algorithm computes n! (that is, the factorial of n) and then records only the last two digits of each factorial. These two‐digit values are added together to form an intermediate key K. Finally, the sum of the digits of K is calculated, and the encryption code is obtained by taking the ratio of that digit sum to the total number of terms (7), with the ratio simplified as a common fraction.

Determine the simplified fraction that represents the encryption code.

Let A = 20⁴ + 6·20² + 9 – 19⁴.

(a) Without using a calculator, determine the largest prime factor of A.

(b) Suppose A (in dollars) is the total bill for a bulk purchase. The seller offers a discount, but only one of the following discount rates—20%, 25%, or 30%—results in a final (discounted) price that is an integer. Identify that discount rate and then compute the sum of the digits of the discounted price.

Let n be a positive even integer. Find the smallest such n for which there exist n different positive integers b₁, b₂, …, bₙ satisfying all of the following conditions:

(1) The least common multiple b₁, b₂, …, bₙ equals 2310.

  (Note: 2310 = 2·3·5·7·11.)

(2) For every pair of distinct indices i and j, the greatest common divisor gcd(bᵢ, bⱼ) is strictly greater than 1.

(3) The product b₁·b₂·…·bₙ is a perfect cube and is divisible by 2⁶.

(4) Exactly half of the numbers b₁, b₂, …, bₙ are even.

Determine this smallest possible n and describe all n‑tuples (b₁, b₂, …, bₙ) satisfying the above conditions. 

Assume that you may need to consider separate cases according to the placement of the factor 2 among the bᵢ’s in order to satisfy both the lcm condition and the exact count of even numbers.

A shipping container has a rectangular shape. When empty, its width is w, its length is w + 4, and its height is 8. If the interior space diagonal (running from one bottom corner to the opposite top corner) measures exactly 12 units when the container is empty, find the value of w. Then, if the container is loaded so that its length compresses by 1 unit (that is, its effective length becomes w + 3 while the width and height remain unchanged), calculate the new length of the space diagonal for the loaded container.

Team A grades a slope at an elevation change rate of –7/9 miles per hour, while Team B’s initial rate is –6/7 miles per hour. 

(a) Determine which team achieved a gentler slope (remember: a less negative rate means a gentler descent). 

(b) If rough soil conditions cause Team B’s rate to drop by an additional 1/14 (making its rate more negative), re-evaluate which team has the gentler slope.
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question: In an orchard, only 2 out of every 4 trees bear a high yield of fruits. Moreover, a rare songbird species is found in just 1 out of every 7 trees, but note that this bird can only be observed if the tree was planted in the morning. Additionally, only 3 out of 5 trees develop vibrant blossoms. If 75% of the trees were planted in the afternoon, what is the probability that a randomly selected tree simultaneously bears a high yield of fruits, hosts a visible rare songbird, and develops vibrant blossoms?
Let n be a positive integer. Evaluate (–2/5)ⁿ × (5/2)ⁿ and express your answer in simplest form. Then determine for which values of n the result is 1 and for which values it is –1.
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
Consider all positive integers less than 50,000 that can be written in the form
  (2n + 2)² – (2n)²   with n a nonnegative integer.

(a) How many such numbers are there?

(b) Among these numbers, some are divisible by 3. Find how many.

(c) Let S be the sum of those numbers from part (b) that are divisible by 3. What is the remainder when S is divided by 1000?

Hint: Note that
  (2n + 2)² – (2n)² = 4[(n + 1)² – n²] = 4(2n + 1) = 8n + 4.
Also, be sure to determine the range of n so that 8n + 4 < 50,000, and then use modular arithmetic to select the n’s that give numbers divisible by 3.

A water reservoir is being filled over time according to the function V(t) = (1000 + 3t)t, where V represents the volume of water in gallons and t is the time in hours. 

(a) Using the definition of the derivative (the limit definition), find an expression for the instantaneous rate of change dV/dt of the volume V(t).

(b) Additionally, if the reservoir has a leak that drains water at a constant rate of 50 gallons per hour, determine the net rate of change of the water volume at any time t by combining your result from part (a) with the effect of the leak.

A boutique electronics store uses the function
  P(x) = ln(2x + √(1 + 4x²)) + 10
to set the price (in dollars) of a gadget based on a timing parameter x. When a customer chooses to pay on the regular schedule (at “time” x = t), the gadget costs exactly $14. However, the store offers a special early‐payment promotion: if a customer pays exactly t days earlier (using x = –t), the price calculated by the function is further reduced by an extra $2 discount.

(a) Determine the computed price P(–t) (before the extra discount) for the early-payment option.
  Hint: Show that P(–t) and P(t) have a relationship that can simplify your work.

(b) Calculate the final price a customer pays when taking the early-payment option (i.e. after subtracting the extra $2 discount).

(c) Find the percentage discount this final early-payment price represents compared to the regular price of $14.

Two museums, A and B, are built along the curved edge of a circular park. A sculptures exhibit P is installed along the park’s boundary on the minor arc AB. Two additional exhibits Q and R (with Q ≠ P and R ≠ P) are later arranged on the boundary so that visitors walking along the park’s edge from A reach P and Q after covering the same distance, and visitors walking from B reach P and R after covering the same distance. The museums plan a combined outdoor event and decide to set up a central information booth at the point X where the straight paths AR and BQ (drawn as chords of the circle) cross. Prove that X is exactly the reflection of exhibit P across the straight line joining museums A and B.

Let x, y, and z be positive numbers representing the proportions of three ingredients in a special blend. They satisfy
  x + 1⁄(2y) = 5,
  y + 1⁄(3z) = 2,
  z + 1⁄(4x) = 8⁄3.
Find the value of 12·x·y·z.

On a circular race track there are n ≥ 4 checkpoints. At each checkpoint a runner receives a nonzero positive integer number of energy units (each at most 9) that is used to cover the segment up to the next checkpoint. Two runners, starting at two different checkpoints, each record in order (clockwise) the energy values at the next n – 1 checkpoints. Surprisingly, their recorded (n – 1)-term sequences are identical, and in addition the total energy recorded is less than 100 units.

(a) Prove that the checkpoints can be partitioned into several contiguous segments (arcs) so that the sum of energy units along each segment is the same.

(b) Determine all possible values of n which allow such an arrangement.

Hint: You may need to consider separately the cases where n – 1 and the common segment sum have nontrivial common factors.

A school is ordering party favors with a fixed budget of $84 that must be divided equally among A students (where A is a single nonzero digit). At the same time, the order confirmation number is given as 4A72 and is considered valid only if it is divisible by 8. For how many digit values of A are both conditions satisfied?

An electronics manufacturer models its production‐cost adjustment factor (in dollars) with the equation
  y·[y(y + 8) + 16] + 24 = y³ + 9y² + 2y − 96.
(a) Solve for y. (b) Since a negative value of y does not represent a valid cost adjustment, discard any negative solutions. Moreover, if the valid y turns out to be greater than 15, the manufacturer qualifies for a bulk discount that reduces the adjustment by 10%. Determine the final cost adjustment factor used by the manufacturer.
secondary_category: 6.2 Optimal Control, Variational Methods, and Optimization

question: A construction company is designing a rectangular park whose center lies at the origin. One of the park’s opposite vertices is located at P(4.5, p) while the other is given as Q(q, –3). Because P and Q are diametrically opposite vertices, they must be symmetric with respect to the origin. In addition, to achieve an aesthetically pleasing design, the longer side of the park must be exactly 50% greater than the shorter side. Determine the value of p + q.

(1) A rectangular garden has its length given by (x – 5) and its width given by (x – 8). When the area is expanded, it can be written in the form x² + Mx + N. Find the values of M and N.

(2) A company’s quarterly profit (in thousands of dollars) is modeled by the quadratic expression (x + a)(x + b), which expands to x² + 6x + 216⁄25. It is also known that a and b are positive numbers in the ratio 2 : 3.
  (i) Find the value of (a + 2)(b + 2).
  (ii) Compute the sum 1⁄a² + 1⁄b².
secondary_category: 2.2 Ring Theory, Field Theory, and Polynomial Algebra

question:
Let f(x) = x² + 2ax + b (with a, b ∈ ℝ) represent the elevation in meters along a hiking trail at time x (in hours). It is known that the hiker reaches sea level at time x = 3, so that
  f(3) = 0.
In addition, because of varying terrain the effective elevation is modeled by the adjusted function
  g(x) = f(x) – x + a.
The two distinct real roots r₁ and r₂ of g(x) = 0 (with r₁ < r₂) indicate the times when the hiker crosses sea level. Suppose that these crossings occur at times satisfying
  r₁ ∈ (0, 1)  and  r₂ ∈ (4, 5).
Finally, if a > 0 an extra condition applies: the time interval between the two crossings, r₂ – r₁, must be at least 3 hours.
Determine the range of possible values for the parameter a.
secondary_category: 3.1 Real Analysis, Measure Theory, and Functional Analysis

question:
On seven consecutive mornings, a meteorologist recorded temperatures at dawn as follows (in °C): –5, 3, –2, 0, 4, –1, and 6. Later, it was discovered that the measuring device had a calibration error. To correct the readings, the following adjustments must be made:
• For any recorded temperature strictly below 0°C, add 2°C.
• For any recorded temperature 0°C or above, subtract 1°C.

Determine the average of the corrected temperatures for the week.
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question: In triangle ABC the side‐lengths are AB = 20, BC = 21, and AC = 22. Let M be the point on AC so that AM : MC = 1 : 2 and let N be the point on AB satisfying AN : NB = 2 : 3. Define point D on AC by the condition that ∠ABD = ∠DBC and point E on AB by the condition that ∠ACE = ∠ECB. Let Γ₁ be the circumcircle of triangle AMN and let Γ₂ be the circumcircle of triangle ADE; denote by P (different from A) the second point of intersection of Γ₁ and Γ₂. The ray AP meets side BC at Q. If the ratio BQ : QC, reduced to lowest terms, is m : n with m and n relatively prime positive integers, find m – n.

In tetrahedron ABCD, let point P lie on face BCD and point Q lie on face ACD. They are chosen so that

  ∠BPC = ∠BPD = 135°  and  ∠AQC = ∠AQD = 135°.

Assume further that the lines AP and BQ intersect. Prove that the perpendicular distances from P and Q to the line CD are equal.

Contractor P is twice as efficient as Contractor Q in building walls under normal circumstances. However, due to mandatory safety checks, Contractor P spends 40% of his workday on preparatory review, which effectively reduces his working time. When working together, they complete a wall in 8 days. How many days would Contractor Q, working alone without such safety check delays, require to build the wall?
secondary_category: 6.2 Optimal Control, Variational Methods, and Optimization

question: A driver’s licensing exam consists of two parts: Part I has 16 questions and Part II has 12 questions. In Part I, each correct answer earns 3 points, an unanswered question gives 0 points, and a wrong answer deducts 1 point. In Part II, each correct answer earns 7 points, an unanswered question gives 0 points, and a wrong answer deducts 2 points. Additionally, if a candidate answers at least 10 questions correctly in Part I, they receive a bonus of 4 points; if they answer at least 7 questions correctly in Part II, they receive a bonus of 5 points. If a candidate’s overall score (the sum of points from both parts plus any bonuses) is a prime number, what is the maximum total number of questions the candidate could have answered correctly?

A factory operates two machines whose individual task‐completion times (in hours) are given by the two distinct positive roots of the quadratic equation 4x² – 11x + 6 = 0.

(a) When both machines work together, their combined production rate (in tasks per hour) is the sum of the reciprocals of their individual times. Find this combined production rate in simplest fractional form.

(b) After a technical upgrade, machine B’s task‐completion time is reduced by 25% while machine A’s time remains unchanged. Determine the new combined production rate (in tasks per hour) in simplest fractional form.

In triangle PQR the sides opposite angles P, Q, and R are denoted by p, q, and r respectively, and it is given that q = 4 units.

(1) Suppose that the interior angles P, Q, and R form an arithmetic progression and, in addition, the sum of the smallest and largest angles (that is, P + R) is at least 110°. Under these conditions determine the radius of the circumscribed circle of triangle PQR in terms of the given information.

(2) Now assume instead that the side lengths p, q, and r form an arithmetic progression. For planning purposes the area of triangle PQR is required to be at least 3 square units. Under these constraints find the maximum possible value of the inradius of triangle PQR. (In your solution, carefully analyze the cases permitted by the triangle inequality together with the area constraint.)

1. For every real number x, the inequality x² + 5 > 4x holds.
2. For every pair of positive real numbers a and b, the inequality a⁴ + b⁴ ≥ a³b + ab³ is true.
3. In a bank account with a principal of 500 and continuously compounded interest at a positive rate r, the balance at time t is given by f(t) = 500·e^(rt). For every t ≥ 0, it is claimed that f(t) + 50 > 1.1·f(t).

Determine how many of the above three statements are always true.

A: 0  B: 1  C: 2  D: 3
secondary_category: 3.1 Real Analysis, Measure Theory, and Functional Analysis

question: A solar power company begins with an inventory of 200 solar panels. Every quarter, the company receives a shipment that consists of 3 crates. In non‐peak quarters, each crate contains x solar panels, but during peak quarters—a bonus period occurring 4 times over 2 years—each crate contains (x + 5) panels. After 2 years (8 quarters), the company’s total inventory is 500 panels. What is the value of x?
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
In trapezoid ABCD with AB ∥ CD (with AB being the shorter base), a park is designed in which two circular flowerbeds are installed as water‐features. The first flowerbed, with center O₁ and radius r₁, is constructed so that it is tangent to sides AD, AB, and to diagonal AC. The second flowerbed, with center O₂ and radius r₂, is constructed so that it is tangent to sides BC, CD, and also tangent to the same diagonal AC. Let P be the point where the circle with center O₁ touches side AB and let Q be the point where the circle with center O₂ touches side CD.

In addition it is given that 
  (1) the ratio of the radii satisfies r₁ : r₂ = AD : BC, and 
  (2) the sum of the areas of the two flowerbeds is exactly 50% of the area of the trapezoid.

Prove that the other diagonal BD, the diagonal AC, and the segment PQ all pass through a common point. Moreover, determine the ratio in which this common point divides diagonal AC.

Three colleagues—A, B, and C—each start with a different amount of money in their wallets: A with a dollars, B with b dollars, and C with c dollars. They agree to share money over three rounds, but each transfer incurs a 10% transaction fee (that is, 10% of every transferred amount is lost and does not reach the recipient):

1. In the first round, A gives B an amount equal to 50% of B’s original money. (That is, A transfers 0.5·b dollars; after a 10% fee, B actually receives 90% of that transfer.)
2. In the second round, B gives C an amount equal to 150% of C’s current money (after round 1). (B transfers 1.5 times C’s present amount; after the 10% fee, C receives 90% of that sum.)
3. In the third round, C gives A an amount equal to 75% of A’s current money (after rounds 1 and 2). (C transfers 0.75 times A’s updated amount; after the fee, A receives 90% of that transfer.)

At the end of these three rounds, each colleague finds that exactly $100 remains in their wallet. Assuming all transfers can be made exactly as described, determine the original amounts a, b, and c.

Let f(x) = x² + 3x + t, where t is a natural number with t ≥ 7. Assume that

  (1) f(0), f(1), …, f(⌊√(t/4)⌋) are prime numbers, and  
  (2) t + 2 is a prime number.

Prove that under these assumptions the numbers f(0), f(1), …, f(t – 3) are all primes.

A retailer sells 12 unique items whose prices are 1, 2, 3, …, 12 dollars respectively. For every non‐empty bundle (i.e. every non‐empty subset of these items), the store offers a discount on the bundle’s total price: if the bundle contains an odd number of items, the discount is 10% of the bundle’s price; if it contains an even number of items, the discount is 5% of the bundle’s price. Let D be the total discount amount summed over all non‐empty bundles. Express D in a closed form.

Let n be a positive integer representing the number of team members in a project. In a brainstorming session, any nonempty group of team members may contribute an idea. When exactly k members contribute (with 1 ≤ k ≤ n), one of them is chosen as the lead innovator and each contributing member “amplifies” the idea by a factor of 2; accordingly, the efficiency gain for that group is measured as 
  k · 2^(k–1).
Since there are C(n, k) ways to choose k contributors, the total efficiency gain (summing over all nonempty groups) is

  S = ∑ₖ₌₁ⁿ k · C(n, k) · 2^(k–1).

Prove that

  ∑ₖ₌₁ⁿ k · C(n, k) · 2^(k–1) = n · 3^(n–1).

Additionally, provide both a combinatorial argument and a calculus‐based derivation to establish this identity.

Let a, b, and c be three distinct real numbers satisfying a + b + c = 0. Define the function

  F(x) = a³·[(x – b)/(a – b)]·[(x – c)/(a – c)] + b³·[(x – c)/(b – c)]·[(x – a)/(b – a)] + c³·[(x – a)/(c – a)]·[(x – b)/(c – b)].

(a) Prove that F(x) can be written in closed‐form as

  F(x) = x³ – (x – a)(x – b)(x – c).

(b) Using the additional condition a + b + c = 0, expand F(x) fully and determine the coefficient of x.

(c) Find all real numbers x for which F(x) = x³.
secondary_category: 2.2 Ring Theory, Field Theory, and Polynomial Algebra

question:
Platform A of an amusement park oscillates vertically according to 
  f(t) = 15·sin((π/10)·t – π/8)
and Platform B oscillates according to 
  g(t) = 15·sin((π/10)·t + π/12),
with time t measured in seconds.

(a) Calculate the vertical displacement of each platform at t = 4 seconds and at t = 8 seconds, and state which platform is higher (in absolute displacement) at each time.

(b) During peak hours the ride’s intensity increases so that each platform’s amplitude grows by 20%. Determine the new displacements at t = 4 seconds and t = 8 seconds, and compare the platforms again.

(c) Discuss how the phase shifts (–π/8 for Platform A and +π/12 for Platform B) affect the comparison at these time points. In your analysis, explain why the relative height ordering might change between t = 4 seconds and t = 8 seconds.

In a company, employee bonuses are distributed monthly following a triangular schedule. In month 1 the single bonus is US$100. In month 2 two bonuses are disbursed—the bonuses form a continuous increasing sequence that increases by US$100 from one bonus to the next, so they are US$200 and US$300. In month 3 the three bonuses are US$400, US$500, and US$600; in month 4 they are US$700, US$800, US$900, and US$1000; and the pattern continues such that the first bonus in month n is given by 100 × (1 + 1 + 2 + 3 + … + (n – 1)). In addition, if the month number is even, a 10% tax is deducted from every bonus in that month. Determine the net bonus received by the second employee in the 8th month.

In a triangular park, the side between points A and B is 20% longer than the side between A and C (so AB = 1.2·AC, with AB > AC). From vertex A, the park’s designer constructs the median AM to side BC and the angle bisector AD (with D lying on BC). To install a decorative feature, a point E is chosen on median AM so that a straight pathway drawn through E parallel to side AC meets AD at point F with the property that F is the foot of the perpendicular from E onto AD.

(a) Prove that such a point E is uniquely determined by the given conditions.  
(b) Show that the ratio AE : EM is independent of the overall size of triangle ABC (i.e. it is constant for all such triangles obeying AB = 1.2·AC).  
(c) Determine the numerical value of the ratio AE : EM.

In an after‐school program with 90 students, each student enrolls in exactly one activity: painting, dancing, or singing. There are 40 students in painting, 30 in dancing, and the remaining students in singing. The program has 50 boys and 40 girls. It is given that 15 boys are enrolled in painting and 12 girls are enrolled in dancing. In addition, among the 30 students in dancing, 8 are new transfers, exactly half of whom are boys. Determine the number of boys enrolled in singing.

Let T(x) = 1⁄(x – 5)² – 2x + cos 2θ – 4 sin θ + 3, where x represents a load‐parameter (in appropriate units) and is restricted to x ∈ (–∞, 5) (so that the singularity at x = 5 lies just outside the operating range). This function models the tension (in kilonewtons) in a support cable. To guarantee safe operation, the cable’s tension must always exceed 2 kN; that is, T(x) > 2 for every x in (–∞, 5). Determine the range of the parameter θ (with θ ∈ (0, π)) for which the inequality T(x) > 2 holds for all allowable values of x.

Solve for all values of x in [0, 2π) that satisfy

  sin⁴x + cos⁴x = 1.5·sin2x + 0.25.

After finding the general solutions, determine which of them also meet the condition

  sin x · cos x > 0.
secondary_category: 3.1 Real Analysis, Measure Theory, and Functional Analysis

question:
For every real number t, define u = 2^t and consider the point

  x = u + 3  and  y = u² – 5u + 8.

(a) Express y as a function of x and identify the type of curve traced by these points.

(b) Find the vertex of this curve.

(c) In a physics experiment, x represents the time (in hours, after a three‐hour adjustment) at which a sensor measures a signal’s intensity given by y. Determine the minimum signal intensity (i.e. the minimum value of y) and the corresponding time t (expressed as a function of u if needed).

A 90‐meter long straight park pathway has three marked points A, C, and B arranged in that order so that the ratio of AC to CB is 1 : 2. A new triangular garden is to be established with its base along AB and its third vertex P located off the pathway. The design requires that the foot of the perpendicular from P to AB is exactly at C and that ∠A of triangle APB is exactly three times ∠B.

(a) Determine the height of the garden—that is, the perpendicular distance from P to AB—and find the measures of ∠A and ∠B.

(b) Find all conditions on the location of P (or equivalently, on the lengths of sides AP and BP) so that every side of triangle APB is longer than 40 meters.

Let a, b, and c be the side‐lengths (in meters) of a nondegenerate triangle and suppose that

  a² + b² > 7c².

(a) Prove that under this assumption the side whose length is c must be the shortest side of the triangle.

(b) A municipal park is planned with a triangular shape having perimeter 120 meters. The park’s design calls for a special ornamental fence costing $50 per meter along the shortest side (the remaining two sides will use a less expensive material). Determine, with justification, the maximum possible expenditure on the expensive fencing under the given conditions.

An engineering firm is designing a triangular ramp for accessibility. The ramp’s three sides—denoted by a, b, and c and lying opposite the angles A, B, and C, respectively—must satisfy the following design requirements:

1. The horizontal component of side c (that is, its projection along the direction making angle A with side a) is 6 meters; in other words, c · cos A = 6.
2. The vertical lift provided by the ramp, which equals the projection of side a perpendicular to side c, is 4 meters; that is, a · sin C = 4.
3. For safety, the area of the ramp must be exactly 20 square meters.
4. Due to space constraints, the length of side b is fixed at 80% of the length of side c.

Determine:
 (1) The length of side c.
 (2) The perimeter of the ramp.

At a construction site, weather conditions affect inspectors’ accuracy. On a good-weather day (which occurs 70% of the time), Inspector A correctly identifies a defective material 90% of the time while Inspector B does so 80% of the time. On a poor-weather day (30% chance), their rates drop to 75% and 65% respectively. If a material is defective, what is the overall probability that both inspectors correctly identify it as defective?

A particular chemical reaction has a rate constant k that varies inversely with the cube of the temperature difference ΔT (in Kelvin) from a baseline of 300 K. That is, k = c⁄(ΔT)³ for some constant c. If k = 0.125 s⁻¹ when ΔT = 5 K, then:

a) Find the value of k when ΔT = 8 K.

b) Assuming the reactant’s concentration decays according to C(t) = C₀ · e^(–kt), determine the time t (in seconds) required for the concentration to drop to 25% of its initial value at the new temperature difference.

Six hundred identical regular 80‐sided floor tiles are fixed on a large hall’s surface in arbitrary positions and orientations. A flexible rope is then stretched tightly around all the tiles, so that it forms a closed convex polygon whose vertices always lie at a vertex of one of the tiles (if the rope happens to coincide with an entire side of a tile, count only that side’s endpoints as vertices). Prove that the convex polygon outlined by the rope must have at least 80 vertices.

An architect is designing a rectangular park where the ratio of its length to its width is 5 to 8. Initially, the park’s length measures 0.96 kilometers. However, due to a design modification, the width must be increased by 20% while the overall proportions are maintained. What is the total perimeter of the redesigned park (in kilometers)?
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
A manufacturer marks up its product by 40% over the base production cost to set an initial retail price. Later, to boost sales, the company plans a promotion with two discount schemes applied to the initial price:

• For orders of up to 15 units, the final price per unit should be only 20% above the base cost.
• For orders of more than 15 units, the final price per unit should be only 10% above the base cost.

Determine the discount percentage that must be applied to the initial retail price for each case.
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
Let g(x) = arccos(sin x) with all functions evaluated in radians.

(a) Compute g(4).

(b) Find all solutions for x in the interval [0, 2π] that satisfy sin x = sin 4.

(c) Given that g is differentiable at x = 4, use the chain rule to find g′(4), expressing your answer in its simplest form.

Consider a road whose centerline is modeled by a continuously differentiable function y = f(x) for x between 0 and 100 meters. Its exact length is given by the integral L = ∫₀¹⁰⁰ √[1 + (f ′(x))²] dx. In order to approximate L using numerical integration, a surveyor makes the following assertions:

① The precise road length is determined solely by evaluating the integral ∫₀¹⁰⁰ √[1 + (f ′(x))²] dx, regardless of external measurement conditions.  
② If the road is divided into two segments—one entirely flat (where f ′(x) = 0) and one curved—the approximation error should be computed separately for each segment to achieve an overall reliable estimate.  
③ When applying Simpson’s Rule, the percentage error of the approximation is directly proportional to the number of subintervals into which [0, 100] is divided.  
④ For a road with varying curvature, using a single global error estimate (instead of a piecewise analysis) may underestimate the true total error, which requires case‐by‐case evaluation according to each segment’s characteristics.

Determine which of the above statements are always correct.  
(Express your answer by listing the corresponding sequence numbers.)

A coffee shop sells 8 different coffee blends with original prices P₁, P₂, …, P₈ (in dollars). For a special promotion, the shop increases each price by the same fixed surcharge d, so that each new price is Qᵢ = Pᵢ + d. It is observed that the sum of the new prices’ average and the new prices’ range (the difference between the highest and lowest Qᵢ) is exactly 6 dollars more than the sum of the original average price and the original range. In addition, the promotion rules require that the surcharge d is exactly half of the original price range. Determine the value of d and the original price range.
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
For each positive integer n, a city’s planning committee designs a park modification as follows. At stage n the committee uses a planning parameter aₙ (with a₁ = 2) to define a straight walking path and an adjoining circular green area. The walking path is the line

  Lₙ: y = 2x − √(5n + 4),

and the circular park is given by

  Cₙ: x² + y² = 4aₙ + 3n.

The line Lₙ and the circle Cₙ intersect at two distinct points Aₙ and Bₙ. Their chord length |AₙBₙ| is used to update the planning parameter according to the rules:
 • If n is odd, aₙ₊₁ = (1/3)·|AₙBₙ|².
 • If n is even, aₙ₊₁ = (1/3)·|AₙBₙ|² + 2.

Determine an explicit formula for aₙ in terms of n that takes into account the different cases for odd and even n.

A secure vault uses a 5‐digit access code. For safety, the product of the digits in the code must equal 120, and the code cannot begin with 0. In addition, any code whose first digit is divisible by 3 is marked as high priority. Determine:

(a) How many valid access codes satisfy the product condition?

(b) Among these, how many are high‐priority codes?

In triangle ABC with AB = AC, choose a point D on side BC so that BD : DC = 1 : 2. Let ω be a circle that passes through D and is tangent to line BC at D, with the additional assumption that ω’s center lies inside triangle ABC. Denote by Γ the circumcircle of triangle ABC, and suppose that ω meets Γ (aside from the common point D) at two distinct points M and N. The line MN meets sides AB and AC at points P and Q, respectively, and it is given that MN cuts the segment joining D to the midpoint K of side AB in the ratio DK : KK′ = 2 : 3 (where K′ is the point on DK so that DK′ = 2/5·DK). 

Prove that the circumcircle of triangle PBQ always passes through the circumcenter O of triangle ABC.

(You may need to consider different cases depending on the relative positions of D and K, and use techniques involving homothety and inversion in circle geometry.)

Consider the following four statements concerning real‐world conditions and their logical implications. Determine which of the statements are correctly formulated.

(I) Let the proposition be: “For every day in a given month, the maximum discount offered by a store is at most 30%.” Its negation is given as: “There exists at least one day in that month during which the maximum discount exceeds 30%.”

(II) Consider the claim: “All gold‐tier credit card holders automatically receive free lounge access.” Its negation is stated as: “No gold‐tier credit card holder receives free lounge access.”

(III) In a promotional raffle, two mutually exclusive prizes are offered: a luxury car (event E) and an exotic vacation (event F). Note that if E and F are complementary (meaning that exactly one of the two events must occur), then it is necessary that E and F are mutually exclusive—but mutual exclusivity alone does not guarantee that the two events are complementary. In other words, the condition “E and F are mutually exclusive” is a necessary but not sufficient condition for “E and F are complementary.”

(IV) Let p and q denote the quarterly profit percentages (in percent) for two business divisions. The following condition is proposed: “Having both p > 3 and q > 3 is sufficient but not necessary for the combined performance to satisfy p + q > 7 and p·q > 9.”

Which of these four statements are logically and mathematically valid?

A landscaping company is designing a parabolic garden archway. The original height (in meters) above the ground as a function of horizontal distance x (in meters) from the arch’s center is modeled by

  H(x) = –0.5x² + 3x + 4.

To meet client specifications, the design is altered in two steps:
  1. The arch is raised uniformly by 1 meter.
  2. Its horizontal width is increased by 50% (i.e., every x in the expression is replaced by x/1.5).

a) Find the explicit equation for the modified arch’s height H(x) after these changes.

b) Rewrite your answer in vertex form, H(x) = a(x – h)² + k, and determine the vertex (h, k) of the new arch, which represents the point of maximum height.
secondary_category: 3.1 Real Analysis, Measure Theory, and Functional Analysis

question:
Let f be a bijection from the set {1, 2, …, 101} to itself. We call f “balanced” if for every two positive integers x and y with |x – y| > 10^12 the following inequality holds:
  (1/(x + 1))·GCD(x + 1, y + f(1)) + (1/(x + 2))·GCD(x + 2, y + f(2)) + … + (1/(x + 101))·GCD(x + 101, y + f(101)) < 0.005 · |x – y|.
Determine all balanced bijections f.

A box contains 6 green, 4 red, and 5 blue candies.

(a) Two candies are drawn sequentially without replacement. What is the probability—expressed as a percentage—that the first candy drawn is green and the second candy drawn is blue?

(b) In a modified scenario, if the first candy drawn turns out to be red, it is immediately replaced into the box before drawing the second candy; however, if a green or blue candy is drawn first, it is not replaced. Under this rule, what is the probability—expressed as a decimal rounded to three places—that the drawing sequence yields a red candy first followed by a green candy?

Gabriel is preparing gift bags for 10 employees using gift cards. He currently has 75 gift cards. He plans to put a different number of cards in each bag so that every employee gets at least 5 cards and no two employees receive the same number of cards. After handing out the cards, the number remaining must be a perfect square. In addition, if the bag with the fewest cards contains exactly 5 cards, then the bag with the most cards must hold at least 8 more cards than the bag with the second‐most cards. What is the minimum number of extra gift cards Gabriel must obtain to satisfy all these conditions?

A rectangular park measures 24 meters by 18 meters. At each corner of the park, a fountain is to be installed at the centroid of the triangle formed by the other three vertices. Label these centroids as F₍A₎, F₍B₎, F₍C₎, and F₍D₎ corresponding to vertices A, B, C, and D (that is, F₍A₎ is the centroid of triangle BCD, etc.). When the fountains are connected in order to form a walking path encircling the inner quadrilateral, determine the ratio of this path’s total length (its perimeter) to the perimeter of the park. Express your answer as a percentage.

Let {Sₙ} be a sequence defined as follows: S₀ = 0 and for each integer n ≥ 1, 

  Sₙ = Sₙ₋₁ + dₙ,

where {dₙ} is a sequence of positive real numbers representing installment costs. Assume that:

  (i) The sequence {dₙ} is strictly decreasing; and

  (ii) For every integer n ≥ 2, the percentage decrease satisfies
    (dₙ₋₁ − dₙ)⁄dₙ₋₁ ≥ 5%.

Define the average installment cost for the first n + 1 periods by

  Cₙ = Sₙ⁄(n + 1).

(a) Prove that the sequence {Cₙ} is monotonically decreasing for all n ≥ 1.

(b) Determine if the conclusion still holds if the denominator is changed to n (i.e. if we define Aₙ = Sₙ⁄n for n ≥ 1), and justify your answer with a case analysis.

In a community garden project, a designer plans to install 8 rectangular garden beds. Each bed must have side lengths measured in whole meters, and the ratio of its longer side to its shorter side is required to be one of exactly these four values: 1, 3⁄2, 2, or 5⁄2. Prove that at least two of the garden beds will have the same length‐to‐width ratio.

At a scholarly symposium, each researcher belongs to one of two fields—Mathematics or Physics—and exchanges letters only with colleagues in the same field. Two researchers form a mutual correspondence if each sends a letter to the other. In each field, prove that the number of researchers who end up with an odd number of mutual correspondences is even.

Three machines A, B, and C in a factory have defect rates expressed as positive integer percentages. They satisfy

  A·B + C = 90  
  B·C + A = 90  
  A·C + B = 90

It is known that exactly two of the machines have the same defect rate while the third is different. Determine (a) the sum A + B + C of the defect rates and (b) the product of the smallest and largest defect rates.

In base 8, determine the digits represented by A and B (each a digit from 0 to 7) that satisfy the following addition problem:

    A 4 B₈  
  +  3 B₈  
  –––––––  
   2 0 2₈

Once you have found A and B, form the two‐digit decimal number AB (with A as the tens digit and B as the ones digit); interpret this number as the price in dollars of a concert ticket. If four friends buy tickets together and qualify for a 15% discount on their total purchase, what is the final dollar amount they pay?
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
Seventy‐five distinct packages labeled 1, 2, 3, …, 75 are loaded in a queue so that package 1 is at the front and package 75 is at the back. A processing system works in cycles as follows. In the 1st cycle, an operator removes the top package, “flips” it (that is, simply turns it over without changing its label) and immediately returns it to the front of the queue. In the 2nd cycle the operator removes the top two packages as a block, reverses the order of these two packages, and places the entire block back at the front. In general, in the iᵗʰ cycle the top i packages are removed as a block, their order is reversed, and they are returned to the front in that new order. When i reaches 75, the entire queue is taken as a block, its order reversed, and then replaced. Immediately following the 75th cycle the process repeats starting with “flipping” just the top package on cycle 76, then the top two on cycle 77, and so on.

Now suppose that in addition to these operations, every 100ᵗʰ cycle the entire queue undergoes an external quality‐control check (which does not change any labels or the package order but is noted in the processing log).

Prove that after a finite number of cycles the packages will return to their original order (i.e. package 1 again at the front, package 2 second, etc.). Moreover, show that the total number of cycles needed is a common multiple of both 75 and 100; finally, express this minimal number of cycles as a percentage relative to 75 cycles (that is, determine the ratio (number of cycles ÷ 75) × 100% for the first occurrence when the original order is restored).

A circular park has a fountain whose circular base has center O and radius R. Two oak trees are planted at distinct points T and U along the fountain’s edge. A bench is installed at point B outside the fountain so that OB = 3L (with L a positive constant) and the two lines BT and BU make a right angle at B. Let M be the midpoint of the chord TU and N the midpoint of the segment OB. In addition, suppose that due to landscaping requirements the distance from O to the chord TU is exactly one‐half of R. Find an expression for the distance MN in terms of R and L in its simplest form, and justify your answer.

Find all real numbers x (with x ≠ 0) satisfying

  √(x – 2/x) + √(2 – 2/x) = 2x – 1,

where the expressions under the square roots must be nonnegative.
secondary_category: 3.1 Real Analysis, Measure Theory, and Functional Analysis

question:
Let f: ℝ → ℝ be a differentiable function satisfying, for all real numbers x and y,
  4 + f(x)·f(y) ≤ (xy)/2 + 4·f(x + y + 2) + (x − y)².
In addition, assume that f(0) ≥ 0.
Determine all such functions f.

In a bakery, the ratio of croissants (p) to muffins (q) in a display is such that a special promotional discount is offered on each pastry. The discount is calculated by adding a fixed amount of 1/8 dollar to a variable amount given by (2q – p)/(5q + 3p) dollars. If the total discount per pastry is exactly 0.50 dollars and the bakery has 3 croissants (that is, p = 3), find the number of muffins (q) in the display.

A manufacturer of high‑precision measuring cups wishes to create a set of cups, each with an integer capacity (in milliliters) that is a multiple of 2. Using these cups, one must be able to measure any whole‐number volume from 12 mL up to 180 mL by pouring the liquid into a single container (the cups are used only to add volume). However, because some cups might be out of service from time to time, the set must be designed to work even if one of the cups is unavailable.

a) Determine a set of 9 cups (each having a capacity that is an integer multiple of 2 mL) that allows measurement of every whole-number volume from 12 mL to 180 mL even if any one cup is out of service. Explain the reasoning behind your cup capacities.

b) In a more demanding version, suppose the manufacturer wishes to design a similar set of cups that maintains the measurement capability even if any two cups are out of service. What is the minimum number of cups required for this case, and how might one choose their capacities? Provide a justification for your answer.

A modern building features a skylight shaped like a right isosceles triangle with each leg measuring 12 meters. Determine the following:
(a) The perimeter of the triangle.
(b) The area of the triangle.
(c) The percentage of the total perimeter that is contributed by the hypotenuse.

In a company bonus distribution, Rs. 200 is shared among three departments—Engineering, Marketing, and Sales—according to these rules:
• For every Rs. 5 awarded to Engineering, Marketing receives an unknown number of paisa and Sales receives 80 paisa.
• Moreover, if Engineering’s bonus exceeds Rs. 50, then Marketing gets an extra bonus equal to 25% of the amount by which Engineering’s bonus exceeds Rs. 50.

It is known that Engineering received Rs. 90 and Sales received Rs. 14.4. Determine the number of paisa that Marketing receives for every Rs. 5 awarded to Engineering (before including the extra bonus).

At a baking facility, 18 ovens can bake 540 loaves of bread in 15 hours. After a technological upgrade, a new bakery is set up with an unknown number of ovens. It is observed that three times the number of ovens in the new bakery, each running 25% more efficiently than before, can bake half of the 540 loaves in 12 hours. How many ovens are installed in the new bakery?
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question: A regular hexagon ABCDEF has all sides measuring 4 units. Side AB is extended past B to point X so that BX = 2·(AB), and side DE is extended past E to point Y so that EY = AB. Find the length of segment XY. Express your answer in simplest radical form.

A contractor is designing a rectangular window in which the length is 1.5 times its width w (in inches). The window’s structural strength is measured by the function S(w) = √(–5w² + 15w + 20), which must be real (i.e. the expression under the square root must be nonnegative). In addition, for aesthetic appeal, the window’s area A = 1.5w² must be at least 10 square inches. Determine all possible integer values of w that satisfy both conditions.
secondary_category: 3.1 Real Analysis, Measure Theory, and Functional Analysis

question:
Consider the following multi‐part problem:

A park designer models a winding walking trail using the parametric equations
  x = √(4 + 2·sinθ),
  y = cos²(π/6 – θ/3),  for 0 ≤ θ < 2π.

(a) Show that the set of points (x, y) described by these equations lies on a conic section. Determine whether the traced curve is part of a parabola or of an ellipse.

(b) The park regulations require that if the trail is parabolic then it must pass through the designated rest area at (1, ½), whereas if it is elliptical it must pass through the observation spot at (–1, ½). Verify which of these conditions holds for the given trail.

(c) Assuming the trail satisfies the correct design condition from part (b), identify the extreme x‐value on the curve (that is, the maximum x reached) and compute the ratio of this x-coordinate to the corresponding y-coordinate at that point.

Solve each part, showing all work and justifying your answers.

A weather station records the temperature in a greenhouse using the function 
  T(t) = 25 + 6·cos(5t – π/2),
where T is in degrees Celsius and t (in hours) covers one complete cycle of the temperature variation. 

(a) Determine the time intervals within one period during which the temperature is rising (that is, when T(t) is monotonically increasing).

(b) Within the intervals found in part (a), identify the subintervals when the temperature exceeds 28°C.

Let S be a finite set of real numbers representing annual interest rates (in percent) offered by a bank. It is known that for any three distinct rates x, y, and z in S with x < y < z, at least one of the following numbers also belongs to S:
  0.4x + 0.6y, 0.4x + 0.6z, 0.4y + 0.6z.
Determine the maximum possible number of elements in S.

At a promotional event, a store marked 80% of its merchandise for a special discount. During the sale, only 90% of these discounted items were sold for $20 each, while the remaining discounted items (as well as the 20% that were never marked for discount) were not sold. If the total revenue from the sold items was $1,080, determine:
a) The total number of items in the store.
b) The number of items that remained unsold.
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
In a city park, an elliptical pond is defined by
  (x²/5) + (y²/8) = 1.
The pond’s two decorative fountains are located at the ellipse’s foci; denote by F the fountain on the positive y‐axis. A straight walking path is laid out through F making an inclination angle of 120° with respect to the positive x‑axis. This path meets the pond’s boundary at two distinct points M and N. Let P be the point obtained by reflecting the park’s center O (the origin) about the midpoint of segment MN.

(1) Determine whether point P lies inside, on, or outside the boundary of the pond.

(2) Compute the area of the quadrilateral formed by the vertices O, M, P, and N.

Let f(n) be a function defined on the integers by

  for n ≤ 7: f(n) = [ –2468/13579 ]^0  
  for n > 7: f(n) = [ –2468/13579 ]^(n – 7)

(a) Evaluate f(7) and f(9).  
(b) Find all integer values of n for which f(n) = 1.  
(c) Find all integer values of n for which f(n) = –2468/13579.

In a community garden project, the design team specifies that the plot’s length L (in meters) and width W (in meters) must satisfy
  (L – 15)² = 49  and  (W – 4)³ = 27.
Furthermore, to optimize sunlight exposure, they require L > 15 and W > 4. For the approved plot, the aesthetic score S is defined by

  S = √L – √(2L·W) + ∛(3W – L).

Determine the value of S.

Let f : ℝ → ℝ be a linear function satisfying

  f(2x² – 3x + 6) + 3·f(3x² + 2x + 4) = 11x² + 3x + 378  for all real numbers x.

In addition, it is given that f(–10) is 20% less than f(10); that is, f(–10) = 0.8·f(10).

Determine f(2015).

a) Evaluate the expression
  [lg√100 + lg 10 − log₂ 8] ÷ [(½)·lg 0.01 + lg 100].

b) A function g defined on the real numbers satisfies
  g(x + 2) − 2·g(x) + g(x − 2) = 3x + 7
for all x. Given that g(0) = 2 and g(2) = 5, find an explicit formula for g(x).

A contractor’s fee is determined by the cost of materials, M, as follows:
 • If M is at most $500, then the fee is $150 plus 150% of M.
 • If M is more than $500, then the fee is 110% of M.
If a project’s total fee is $880, find all possible values for M.
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question: Kevin is planning to build a community sports center. The center’s design allocates 18 square feet per spectator seat, and he plans for 600 seats. In addition, design guidelines require that the seating area be augmented by a 15% lobby area (measured as a percentage of the seating area). The construction cost is normally $12 per square foot, but if the total constructed area (seating plus lobby) exceeds 15,000 square feet, then the cost for every square foot above 15,000 drops to $10. The cost to acquire the land is 1.5 times the total construction cost (calculated using the piecewise rates, if applicable). Kevin’s business partner agrees to cover a fixed percentage of the overall project cost, with Kevin paying the remainder. It turns out that Kevin’s out-of-pocket expense is exactly $216,000. Determine what percentage of the overall project cost was paid by his partner.
secondary_category: 6.2 Optimal Control, Variational Methods, and Optimization

question:
Let m and n be integers with m, n ≥ 4. A public plaza is to be paved exactly with decorative tiles, without gaps or overlaps, so that its floor (an m × n‐meter rectangle) is completely covered. Two types of tiles have been manufactured from pairs of identical right isosceles triangles with legs 3 meters (each triangle has area 9/2, so every tile has area 9):

• An L‐tile is formed by joining the two triangles along one leg. This produces a “bent” isosceles shape whose overall dimensions include a leg of length 3√2 meters.

• A P‐tile is produced by joining the triangles along their hypotenuse. The result is a parallelogram with side lengths 3 and 3√2 meters.

A tiling of the plaza is required to satisfy an extra condition. If the rectangle’s side lengths have different parity (i.e. one is odd and one is even), then the number of L‐tiles used must be exactly twice the number of P‐tiles. On the other hand, if both m and n are even, the tiling must employ equal numbers of L‐tiles and P‐tiles.

Note that, since each tile covers 9 square meters, the total area m·n must be a multiple of 9.

Determine all pairs (m, n) with m, n ≥ 4 for which there exists a tiling of an m × n rectangle with L‐tiles and P‐tiles satisfying the above requirements.

Consider the quadratic equation 
  9x² + 6x + p = 0,
with constant p. Its roots can be written in the form 
  (–6 ± i√q)⁄18,
where q > 0. For each root, the ratio of the magnitude of its imaginary part to the magnitude of its real part is 1:3. In addition, a triangle is constructed whose side lengths are the absolute value of the real part, the absolute value of the imaginary part, and the sum of these two numbers (all taken from one of the roots). Determine the values of p and q and find the perimeter of this triangle.
secondary_category: 2.2 Ring Theory, Field Theory, and Polynomial Algebra

question:
A contractor manages two phases for a renovation project. During Phase 1, he spends 20 minutes inspecting the work site and 50 minutes drafting a repair plan. In Phase 2, he conducts a follow‐up consultation that lasts 35 minutes—this consultation time is exactly the percentage of the total time spent in Phase 1. Moreover, before beginning the consultation, he experiences a waiting period equal to 40% of the consultation duration. 
a) What percentage of the total Phase 1 time does the consultation represent? 
b) How long is the waiting period before the consultation?
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question: At a community festival, student tickets cost 5 dollars each, but a group of students received a 20% discount on their tickets. Overall, 300 tickets were sold for a total of 1860 dollars. Out of the 100 student tickets sold, 40 were bought at the discounted price while the remaining student tickets were sold at full price. Determine the regular price of an adult ticket.
secondary_category: 7.1 Arithmetic and Number Operations: Elementary to Advanced

question:
A city park is being redesigned with a curving walking trail that follows the parabola 
  y² = 8x.
Two key facilities are already in place: a central maintenance shed located at the focus F of the parabola and an information kiosk at point A(–4, 3). For safety and cost‐efficiency reasons, engineers plan to install a new overhead surveillance camera along the straight path connecting A to a mobile service unit P that moves along the trail (with P restricted to the first quadrant). The installation will be optimized when the percentage ratio 
  R = [100·|PF|]⁄|PA|
is minimized. (Here |PF| and |PA| denote the distances from P to F and from P to A, respectively.) 

Determine all possible equations of the line AP that yield the minimum percentage ratio R. In your solution, clearly analyze any cases that arise from the constraints on P.

A museum is designed on a rectangular grid. One straight corridor has an endpoint at (2, 3) and a security sensor located exactly at its midpoint records the coordinates (7, 8). Determine the Manhattan distance between the two endpoints of the corridor (i.e. the sum of the absolute differences of their x- and y-coordinates).

Let a and b be two fixed nonzero real numbers. Determine all triples of polynomials P(x, y, z), Q(x, y, z), and R(x, y, z) with real coefficients and with minimal possible total degree that satisfy
  (x – y + a)⁴ · P(x, y, z) + (y – z – b)⁴ · Q(x, y, z) + (z – 2x + 2)⁴ · R(x, y, z) = x² + y² + z²
for all real numbers x, y, and z. In your solution, analyze separately the cases when a + b = 0 and when a + b ≠ 0.
